content: Obama to Lift Ban on Funding for Embryonic Stem Cell Research March 6, 2009 President Obama is planning to sign an executive order on Monday rolling back restrictions on federal funding of human embryonic stem cell research, according to sources close to the issue. Although the exact wording of the order has not been revealed, the White House plans an 11 a.m. ceremony to sign the order repealing one of the most controversial steps taken by his predecessor, fulfilling one of Obama's eagerly anticipated campaign promises Full article at >>> >http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2009/03/06/AR2009030602285.html?hpid=topnews

content: Anyone intrested can certainly read up on the contracts for major IVF facilities in this country. Embryos are stored for a FEE and should that fee not be paid than the embryos are property of the clinic /storage facility and will be destroyed/disposed of after a certain ammount of time. Feel free to google or even call one and ask. Fertilized eggs flushed are of no value to anyone-discarded embryos used for medical research do however have value.

content: Ethical embryo storage facilities DO NOT "flush" any down the drain. In reality, unless there's been a DOCUMENTED power failure of the back-up generator or a legal document giving permission for destruction after X-ammount of time, all embryos are kept ad infinitum in order to avoid lawsuits. When the decision is made to close the facility, calls are made, registered letters are sent and finally, private detectives - at the clinics expense - are hired trying to find the doners. Then, and only then, will embryos be destroyed. This is not a game nor is it taken lightly. A woman's right to choose is taken very, very seriously in the "ethical" realm of this section of medicine. Remember, the reasons for IVF are many. Those embryos can be just her eggs, to be fertalized later (perhaps he had cancer). Or her husband's sperm (maybe he did). Maybe she's stored a donor's eggs for future pregnancies by the same woman (or sperm). Maybe she just can't carry a pregnancy to term and stores her eggs for a surrogate. Or stores her eggs (or his sperm) because she's/he's being deployed and they want a child, no matter what happens. Infertility ain't fun and sure as he77 ain't fair. And while the methods of solving it may well sound "unnatural" and "wierd", it's a personal decision. THAT'S why it's so important to go someplace reputable. Someplace that will ask you what you want done with any extra embryos you might have. And, yes, stem cell research is an excellent place for them.

A woman has a dozen fertilised embryo's, she used one, two, whatever - What happens to the rest? She's going to keep paying for an embryo that wont be used? So they get rid of them. State laws vary, but they all allow the disposal of unused embryo's. "http://www.ncsl.org/programs/health/embryodisposition.htm" I mean, what else are they going to do with them? As for the point of this thread - Mr. Obama differs little from John McCain. Mr. McCain supports embryo stem cell research with the ONE reservation that the embryo's have to be one of those marked for disposal (i.e. flushing). I find that a reasonable objection on his part. quote: McCain McCain opposes embryonic stem cell research that uses cloned human embryos. In 2006 he supported a trio of U.S. Senate bills designed to increase federal funding for adult stem cell research, ban the creation of embryos for research and offer federal support for research using embryos slated for destruction by fertility clinics. In 2007, in what he described as "a very agonizing and tough decision," he voted to allow research using human embryos left over from fertility treatments. "http://pewforum.org/religion08/compare.php?Issue=Stem_Cell_Research" Dave

content: Well golly......... There's never been a ban on research of embryonic stem cell. Limits on Federal Money while private institutions did their thing. "Although the bill passed the House, new scientific breakthroughs offer the Bush Administration a chance to win the greater stem cell debate. Just days before the House voted to authorize funding, scientists at Wake Forest University announced the discovery of stem cells in amniotic-fluid, which surrounds the fetus in the placenta. Not only do these cells not require killing humans, but they also do not form tumors, a fault of embryonic stem cells. Amniotic cells also share many of the positive, unique attributes of embryonic stem cells". "http://graphic.pepperdine.edu/perspectives/2007/2007-1-25-stemcells.htm" On top of that it seems unnecessary the killing of life or even large sums of money to study the whole issue, but that as it may, Congress should have their say in the matter. Since the President got his trillions to play with we might as well send them home or on another convention somewhere, for the good they do, WE don't need a Congress. Now, please continue your rants and raves that don't prove a damn thing. thank you.

Now, please continue your rants and raves that don't prove a damn thing. thank you. Reading your link above, I must say this is a very dishonest article. I mean no aspersions on you Ray, when I say this - I am talking about the article. 1. The article makes believe that there is no difference between embryo stem cells and these derived from amniotic fluid... quote: But Dr. Anthony Atala, head of Wake Forest’s regenerative medicine institute and the senior researcher on the project, said the scientists still don’t know exactly how many different cell types can be made from the stem cells found in amniotic fluid. The scientists said preliminary tests in patients are years away. "http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/16514457/.htm 2. No loss of life is involved in this Bill. Only those embryos scheduled for flushing down the toilet (presumably the proper and dignified way of honoring human life) will be used. quote: Representatives Introduce Multiple Stem Cell-Related Bills Reps. Diane DeGette (R-Colo.) and Mike Castle (D-Del.) Feb. 4 introduced the "Stem Cell Research Enhancement Act of 2009" (H.R. 873), which would lift the Bush Administration's restriction on federal funding for research using embryonic stem cells created after Aug. 9, 2001. The bill would allow in vitro fertilization clinics to donate embryos for research that otherwise would be discarded. This legislation is similar to legislation previously vetoed by President Bush [see Washington Highlights, June 22, 2007]. A second bill, the "Stem Cell Research Improvement Act of 2009" (H.R. 872), also would allow discarded embryos to be used for research, regardless of the date of creation. However, the bill also includes a more explicit ethical framework in the statute as well as a various reporting requirements [see Washington Highlights, Oct. 3, 2008]. "http://www.aamc.org/advocacy/library/washhigh/2009/022009/start.htm 3. Stem Cell research has yet to pay off in dramatic disease treatment. Par for the course in all new areas of research. But this is not to say they it ain't happening - It's happening right now. quote: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (UPI) -- The U.S. Food and Drug Administration approved the first-ever human trial of a medical treatment derived from embryonic stem cells. "This marks the beginning of what is potentially a new chapter in medical therapeutics -- one that reaches beyond pills to a new level of healing: the restoration of organ and tissue function achieved by the injection of healthy replacement cells," Thomas Okarma, Geron Corp. (NASDAQ:GERN) president and chief executive officer, said in a release announcing the FDA decision. Geron, a California bio-technical company, was approved to begin a study of its stem-cell treatment for spinal cord injuries in up to 10 patients, The Wall Street Journal reported Friday. "If safe and effective, the therapy would provide a viable treatment option for thousands of patients who suffer severe spinal cord injuries each year," said Richard Fessler, professor of neurological surgery professor at Northwestern University. Limits on stem-cell research imposed by the Bush administration have impeded academic and corporate research. President Barack Obama said during the campaign that overturning research limits was a top priority for his administration. Peter Wilderotter, president and CEO of the Christopher & Dana Reeve Foundation, called the human trial the "dawn of basic research being translated into human clinical trials for people living with spinal cord injury." (more) "http://www.upi.com/Science_News/2009/01/23/FDA_OKs_embryonic_stem-cell_human_trial/UPI-56161232728584/ And yes, President Bush did not "ban" stem cell research, but as you well know, without Federal support, it's been almost a moot issue. Labs that do research cannot do stem cell research if they accept any Federal money, and those much abllyhooed "existing" stem cell lines turned out to be mostly useless. Finally, the wording of the Stem Cell Bills deliberately limit it to embryo's that would be normally discarded - i.e. flushed down the john. I personally suspect that 20 years from now therapies derived from this research will present us with dramatic cures for ailments we never thought possible of dealing with. Those who oppose this research (which harms NO LIFE) should immediately swear an oath to never take advantage of them. Dave

content: Ethical embryo storage facilities DO NOT "flush" any down the drain. In reality, unless there's been a DOCUMENTED power failure of the back-up generator or a legal document giving permission for destruction after X-ammount of time, all embryos are kept ad infinitum in order to avoid lawsuits. When the decision is made to close the facility, calls are made, registered letters are sent and finally, private detectives - at the clinics expense - are hired trying to find the doners. Then, and only then, will embryos be destroyed. This is not a game nor is it taken lightly. A woman's right to choose is taken very, very seriously in the "ethical" realm of this section of medicine. Remember, the reasons for IVF are many. Those embryos can be just her eggs, to be fertalized later (perhaps he had cancer). Or her husband's sperm (maybe he did). Maybe she's stored a donor's eggs for future pregnancies by the same woman (or sperm). Maybe she just can't carry a pregnancy to term and stores her eggs for a surrogate. Or stores her eggs (or his sperm) because she's/he's being deployed and they want a child, no matter what happens. Infertility ain't fun and sure as he77 ain't fair. And while the methods of solving it may well sound "unnatural" and "wierd", it's a personal decision. THAT'S why it's so important to go someplace reputable. Someplace that will ask you what you want done with any extra embryos you might have. And, yes, stem cell research is an excellent place for them.

The article makes believe that there is no difference between embryo stem cells and these derived from amniotic fluid... quote: But Dr. Anthony Atala, head of Wake Forest’s regenerative medicine institute and the senior researcher on the project, said the scientists still don’t know exactly how many different cell types can be made from the stem cells found in amniotic fluid. The scientists said preliminary tests in patients are years away. "http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/16514457/.htm 2. No loss of life is involved in this Bill. Only those embryos scheduled for flushing down the toilet (presumably the proper and dignified way of honoring human life) will be used. quote: Representatives Introduce Multiple Stem Cell-Related Bills Reps. Diane DeGette (R-Colo.) and Mike Castle (D-Del.) Feb. 4 introduced the "Stem Cell Research Enhancement Act of 2009" (H.R. 873), which would lift the Bush Administration's restriction on federal funding for research using embryonic stem cells created after Aug. 9, 2001. The bill would allow in vitro fertilization clinics to donate embryos for research that otherwise would be discarded. This legislation is similar to legislation previously vetoed by President Bush [see Washington Highlights, June 22, 2007]. A second bill, the "Stem Cell Research Improvement Act of 2009" (H.R. 872), also would allow discarded embryos to be used for research, regardless of the date of creation. However, the bill also includes a more explicit ethical framework in the statute as well as a various reporting requirements [see Washington Highlights, Oct. 3, 2008]. "http://www.aamc.org/advocacy/library/washhigh/2009/022009/start.htm 3. Stem Cell research has yet to pay off in dramatic disease treatment. Par for the course in all new areas of research. But this is not to say they it ain't happening - It's happening right now. quote: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (UPI) -- The U.S. Food and Drug Administration approved the first-ever human trial of a medical treatment derived from embryonic stem cells. "This marks the beginning of what is potentially a new chapter in medical therapeutics -- one that reaches beyond pills to a new level of healing: the restoration of organ and tissue function achieved by the injection of healthy replacement cells," Thomas Okarma, Geron Corp. (NASDAQ:GERN) president and chief executive officer, said in a release announcing the FDA decision. Geron, a California bio-technical company, was approved to begin a study of its stem-cell treatment for spinal cord injuries in up to 10 patients, The Wall Street Journal reported Friday. "If safe and effective, the therapy would provide a viable treatment option for thousands of patients who suffer severe spinal cord injuries each year," said Richard Fessler, professor of neurological surgery professor at Northwestern University. Limits on stem-cell research imposed by the Bush administration have impeded academic and corporate research. President Barack Obama said during the campaign that overturning research limits was a top priority for his administration. Peter Wilderotter, president and CEO of the Christopher & Dana Reeve Foundation, called the human trial the "dawn of basic research being translated into human clinical trials for people living with spinal cord injury." (more) "http://www.upi.com/Science_News/2009/01/23/FDA_OKs_embryonic_stem-cell_human_trial/UPI-56161232728584/ And yes, President Bush did not "ban" stem cell research, but as you well know, without Federal support, it's been almost a moot issue. Labs that do research cannot do stem cell research if they accept any Federal money, and those much abllyhooed "existing" stem cell lines turned out to be mostly useless. Finally, the wording of the Stem Cell Bills deliberately limit it to embryo's that would be normally discarded - i.e. flushed down the john. I personally suspect that 20 years from now therapies derived from this research will present us with dramatic cures for ailments we never thought possible of dealing with. Those who oppose this research (which harms NO LIFE) should immediately swear an oath to never take advantage of them. Dave

reply: Reading your link above, I must say this is a very dishonest article. I mean no aspersions on you Ray, when I say this - I am talking about the article. 1. The article makes believe that there is no difference between embryo stem cells and these derived from amniotic fluid... quote: But Dr. Anthony Atala, head of Wake Forest’s regenerative medicine institute and the senior researcher on the project, said the scientists still don’t know exactly how many different cell types can be made from the stem cells found in amniotic fluid. The scientists said preliminary tests in patients are years away. "http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/16514457/.htm 2. No loss of life is involved in this Bill. Only those embryos scheduled for flushing down the toilet (presumably the proper and dignified way of honoring human life) will be used. quote: Representatives Introduce Multiple Stem Cell-Related Bills Reps. Diane DeGette (R-Colo.) and Mike Castle (D-Del.) Feb. 4 introduced the "Stem Cell Research Enhancement Act of 2009" (H.R. 873), which would lift the Bush Administration's restriction on federal funding for research using embryonic stem cells created after Aug. 9, 2001. The bill would allow in vitro fertilization clinics to donate embryos for research that otherwise would be discarded. This legislation is similar to legislation previously vetoed by President Bush [see Washington Highlights, June 22, 2007]. A second bill, the "Stem Cell Research Improvement Act of 2009" (H.R. 872), also would allow discarded embryos to be used for research, regardless of the date of creation. However, the bill also includes a more explicit ethical framework in the statute as well as a various reporting requirements [see Washington Highlights, Oct. 3, 2008]. "http://www.aamc.org/advocacy/library/washhigh/2009/022009/start.htm 3. Stem Cell research has yet to pay off in dramatic disease treatment. Par for the course in all new areas of research. But this is not to say they it ain't happening - It's happening right now. quote: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (UPI) -- The U.S. Food and Drug Administration approved the first-ever human trial of a medical treatment derived from embryonic stem cells. "This marks the beginning of what is potentially a new chapter in medical therapeutics -- one that reaches beyond pills to a new level of healing: the restoration of organ and tissue function achieved by the injection of healthy replacement cells," Thomas Okarma, Geron Corp. (NASDAQ:GERN) president and chief executive officer, said in a release announcing the FDA decision. Geron, a California bio-technical company, was approved to begin a study of its stem-cell treatment for spinal cord injuries in up to 10 patients, The Wall Street Journal reported Friday. "If safe and effective, the therapy would provide a viable treatment option for thousands of patients who suffer severe spinal cord injuries each year," said Richard Fessler, professor of neurological surgery professor at Northwestern University. Limits on stem-cell research imposed by the Bush administration have impeded academic and corporate research. President Barack Obama said during the campaign that overturning research limits was a top priority for his administration. Peter Wilderotter, president and CEO of the Christopher & Dana Reeve Foundation, called the human trial the "dawn of basic research being translated into human clinical trials for people living with spinal cord injury." (more) "http://www.upi.com/Science_News/2009/01/23/FDA_OKs_embryonic_stem-cell_human_trial/UPI-56161232728584/ And yes, President Bush did not "ban" stem cell research, but as you well know, without Federal support, it's been almost a moot issue. Labs that do research cannot do stem cell research if they accept any Federal money, and those much abllyhooed "existing" stem cell lines turned out to be mostly useless. Finally, the wording of the Stem Cell Bills deliberately limit it to embryo's that would be normally discarded - i.e. flushed down the john. I personally suspect that 20 years from now therapies derived from this research will present us with dramatic cures for ailments we never thought possible of dealing with. Those who oppose this research (which harms NO LIFE) should immediately swear an oath to never take advantage of them. Dave

content: Ethical embryo storage facilities DO NOT "flush" any down the drain. In reality, unless there's been a DOCUMENTED power failure of the back-up generator or a legal document giving permission for destruction after X-ammount of time, all embryos are kept ad infinitum in order to avoid lawsuits. When the decision is made to close the facility, calls are made, registered letters are sent and finally, private detectives - at the clinics expense - are hired trying to find the doners. Then, and only then, will embryos be destroyed. This is not a game nor is it taken lightly. A woman's right to choose is taken very, very seriously in the "ethical" realm of this section of medicine. Remember, the reasons for IVF are many. Those embryos can be just her eggs, to be fertalized later (perhaps he had cancer). Or her husband's sperm (maybe he did). Maybe she's stored a donor's eggs for future pregnancies by the same woman (or sperm). Maybe she just can't carry a pregnancy to term and stores her eggs for a surrogate. Or stores her eggs (or his sperm) because she's/he's being deployed and they want a child, no matter what happens. Infertility ain't fun and sure as he77 ain't fair. And while the methods of solving it may well sound "unnatural" and "wierd", it's a personal decision. THAT'S why it's so important to go someplace reputable. Someplace that will ask you what you want done with any extra embryos you might have. And, yes, stem cell research is an excellent place for them.

Diane DeGette (R-Colo.) and Mike Castle (D-Del.) Feb. 4 introduced the "Stem Cell Research Enhancement Act of 2009" (H.R. 873), which would lift the Bush Administration's restriction on federal funding for research using embryonic stem cells created after Aug. 9, 2001. The bill would allow in vitro fertilization clinics to donate embryos for research that otherwise would be discarded. This legislation is similar to legislation previously vetoed by President Bush [see Washington Highlights, June 22, 2007]. A second bill, the "Stem Cell Research Improvement Act of 2009" (H.R. 872), also would allow discarded embryos to be used for research, regardless of the date of creation. However, the bill also includes a more explicit ethical framework in the statute as well as a various reporting requirements [see Washington Highlights, Oct. 3, 2008]. "http://www.aamc.org/advocacy/library/washhigh/2009/022009/start.htm 3. Stem Cell research has yet to pay off in dramatic disease treatment. Par for the course in all new areas of research. But this is not to say they it ain't happening - It's happening right now. quote: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (UPI) -- The U.S. Food and Drug Administration approved the first-ever human trial of a medical treatment derived from embryonic stem cells. "This marks the beginning of what is potentially a new chapter in medical therapeutics -- one that reaches beyond pills to a new level of healing: the restoration of organ and tissue function achieved by the injection of healthy replacement cells," Thomas Okarma, Geron Corp. (NASDAQ:GERN) president and chief executive officer, said in a release announcing the FDA decision. Geron, a California bio-technical company, was approved to begin a study of its stem-cell treatment for spinal cord injuries in up to 10 patients, The Wall Street Journal reported Friday. "If safe and effective, the therapy would provide a viable treatment option for thousands of patients who suffer severe spinal cord injuries each year," said Richard Fessler, professor of neurological surgery professor at Northwestern University. Limits on stem-cell research imposed by the Bush administration have impeded academic and corporate research. President Barack Obama said during the campaign that overturning research limits was a top priority for his administration. Peter Wilderotter, president and CEO of the Christopher & Dana Reeve Foundation, called the human trial the "dawn of basic research being translated into human clinical trials for people living with spinal cord injury." (more) "http://www.upi.com/Science_News/2009/01/23/FDA_OKs_embryonic_stem-cell_human_trial/UPI-56161232728584/ And yes, President Bush did not "ban" stem cell research, but as you well know, without Federal support, it's been almost a moot issue. Labs that do research cannot do stem cell research if they accept any Federal money, and those much abllyhooed "existing" stem cell lines turned out to be mostly useless. Finally, the wording of the Stem Cell Bills deliberately limit it to embryo's that would be normally discarded - i.e. flushed down the john. I personally suspect that 20 years from now therapies derived from this research will present us with dramatic cures for ailments we never thought possible of dealing with. Those who oppose this research (which harms NO LIFE) should immediately swear an oath to never take advantage of them. Dave

content: Ethical embryo storage facilities DO NOT "flush" any down the drain. In reality, unless there's been a DOCUMENTED power failure of the back-up generator or a legal document giving permission for destruction after X-ammount of time, all embryos are kept ad infinitum in order to avoid lawsuits. When the decision is made to close the facility, calls are made, registered letters are sent and finally, private detectives - at the clinics expense - are hired trying to find the doners. Then, and only then, will embryos be destroyed. This is not a game nor is it taken lightly. A woman's right to choose is taken very, very seriously in the "ethical" realm of this section of medicine. Remember, the reasons for IVF are many. Those embryos can be just her eggs, to be fertalized later (perhaps he had cancer). Or her husband's sperm (maybe he did). Maybe she's stored a donor's eggs for future pregnancies by the same woman (or sperm). Maybe she just can't carry a pregnancy to term and stores her eggs for a surrogate. Or stores her eggs (or his sperm) because she's/he's being deployed and they want a child, no matter what happens. Infertility ain't fun and sure as he77 ain't fair. And while the methods of solving it may well sound "unnatural" and "wierd", it's a personal decision. THAT'S why it's so important to go someplace reputable. Someplace that will ask you what you want done with any extra embryos you might have. And, yes, stem cell research is an excellent place for them.

content: Well golly......... There's never been a ban on research of embryonic stem cell. Limits on Federal Money while private institutions did their thing. "Although the bill passed the House, new scientific breakthroughs offer the Bush Administration a chance to win the greater stem cell debate. Just days before the House voted to authorize funding, scientists at Wake Forest University announced the discovery of stem cells in amniotic-fluid, which surrounds the fetus in the placenta. Not only do these cells not require killing humans, but they also do not form tumors, a fault of embryonic stem cells. Amniotic cells also share many of the positive, unique attributes of embryonic stem cells". "http://graphic.pepperdine.edu/perspectives/2007/2007-1-25-stemcells.htm" On top of that it seems unnecessary the killing of life or even large sums of money to study the whole issue, but that as it may, Congress should have their say in the matter. Since the President got his trillions to play with we might as well send them home or on another convention somewhere, for the good they do, WE don't need a Congress. Now, please continue your rants and raves that don't prove a damn thing. thank you.

content: quote: Originally posted by rayevinsonsr: Well golly......... There's never been a ban on research of embryonic stem cell. Limits on Federal Money while private institutions did their thing. Amniotic cells also share many of the positive, unique attributes of embryonic stem cells". "http://graphic.pepperdine.edu/perspectives/2007/2007-1-25-stemcells.htm" On top of that it seems unnecessary the killing of life or even large sums of money to study the whole issue, but that as it may, Congress should have their say in the matter. Since the President got his trillions to play with we might as well send them home or on another convention somewhere, for the good they do, WE don't need a Congress. Now, please continue your rants and raves that don't prove a damn thing. thank you. Reading your link above, I must say this is a very dishonest article. I mean no aspersions on you Ray, when I say this - I am talking about the article. 1. The article makes believe that there is no difference between embryo stem cells and these derived from amniotic fluid... quote: But Dr. Anthony Atala, head of Wake Forest’s regenerative medicine institute and the senior researcher on the project, said the scientists still don’t know exactly how many different cell types can be made from the stem cells found in amniotic fluid. The scientists said preliminary tests in patients are years away. "http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/16514457/.htm 2. No loss of life is involved in this Bill. Only those embryos scheduled for flushing down the toilet (presumably the proper and dignified way of honoring human life) will be used. quote: Representatives Introduce Multiple Stem Cell-Related Bills Reps. Diane DeGette (R-Colo.) and Mike Castle (D-Del.) Feb. 4 introduced the "Stem Cell Research Enhancement Act of 2009" (H.R. 873), which would lift the Bush Administration's restriction on federal funding for research using embryonic stem cells created after Aug. 9, 2001. The bill would allow in vitro fertilization clinics to donate embryos for research that otherwise would be discarded. This legislation is similar to legislation previously vetoed by President Bush [see Washington Highlights, June 22, 2007]. A second bill, the "Stem Cell Research Improvement Act of 2009" (H.R. 872), also would allow discarded embryos to be used for research, regardless of the date of creation. However, the bill also includes a more explicit ethical framework in the statute as well as a various reporting requirements [see Washington Highlights, Oct. 3, 2008]. "http://www.aamc.org/advocacy/library/washhigh/2009/022009/start.htm 3. Stem Cell research has yet to pay off in dramatic disease treatment. Par for the course in all new areas of research. But this is not to say they it ain't happening - It's happening right now. quote: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (UPI) -- The U.S. Food and Drug Administration approved the first-ever human trial of a medical treatment derived from embryonic stem cells. "This marks the beginning of what is potentially a new chapter in medical therapeutics -- one that reaches beyond pills to a new level of healing: the restoration of organ and tissue function achieved by the injection of healthy replacement cells," Thomas Okarma, Geron Corp. (NASDAQ:GERN) president and chief executive officer, said in a release announcing the FDA decision. Geron, a California bio-technical company, was approved to begin a study of its stem-cell treatment for spinal cord injuries in up to 10 patients, The Wall Street Journal reported Friday. "If safe and effective, the therapy would provide a viable treatment option for thousands of patients who suffer severe spinal cord injuries each year," said Richard Fessler, professor of neurological surgery professor at Northwestern University. Limits on stem-cell research imposed by the Bush administration have impeded academic and corporate research. President Barack Obama said during the campaign that overturning research limits was a top priority for his administration. Peter Wilderotter, president and CEO of the Christopher & Dana Reeve Foundation, called the human trial the "dawn of basic research being translated into human clinical trials for people living with spinal cord injury." (more) "http://www.upi.com/Science_News/2009/01/23/FDA_OKs_embryonic_stem-cell_human_trial/UPI-56161232728584/ And yes, President Bush did not "ban" stem cell research, but as you well know, without Federal support, it's been almost a moot issue. Labs that do research cannot do stem cell research if they accept any Federal money, and those much abllyhooed "existing" stem cell lines turned out to be mostly useless. Finally, the wording of the Stem Cell Bills deliberately limit it to embryo's that would be normally discarded - i.e. flushed down the john. I personally suspect that 20 years from now therapies derived from this research will present us with dramatic cures for ailments we never thought possible of dealing with. Those who oppose this research (which harms NO LIFE) should immediately swear an oath to never take advantage of them. Dave

Really get more from this site and the net than the super stars of our airways has ever brought us. Enough *****en or my part. Now if they start cloneing Democrats at Emory University I might change my mind.
